div.head: THE FIERY TRIAL.

q.p: Dearely beloued, thinke it not strange concerning the fiery tryall, which thing is to try you, as though some strange thing happened vnto you.

div.p:
AT this 12. verse St. Peter exhorteth the dispersed Iewes to suffer afflictions, euen the fiery affliction: In which exhortation these things are plainly layd down: First, a friendly compellation, in these
words; Dearely beloued: Secondly, a remouing of a wrong and erroneous conceit, touching the fiery affliction, in these words; Thinke it not strange concerning the fiery tryall, as though some strange thing hapned vnto you: Thirdly, a reason to suffer the fiery affliction, in these wordes; Which is to trie you. And it is thus to bee framed: that which tryeth men, as the fire tryeth the gold, is to be suffered; but the fiery affliction tryeth men as the fire trieth the gold, therefore it is to be suffered.

Touching the friendly compellation: Saint Peter vseth it to make his exhortation of greater force, that it may take place with Christians, for men will receiue vsually the exhortations, admonitions, and reproofes of those which loue them; as contrary, they will reiect
and despise the reproofe of them that hate them.
lib. 2. cap. 2. Tres sunt causae (saith Aristotle) quibus efficitur vt ei qui dicit, &c. There are three things that procure of a mans Auditors credite, wisedome, honesty, and loue, wheresoeuer these things are to be found, there the hearers reape benefite and profite; but where they are not, they goe away without a blessing. Hence we learne the sincere loue that should bee betwixt Christians, seeing Peter calleth the Christians dearely beloued. Vnto this duety Saint Iohn in his first Epistle, 3. chap. 18. ver. exhorteth vs, saying: My little children, let vs not loue in word and in tongue, or speech, but in worke and truth. There are many arguments to perswade Christians to loue one another: First, afflictions; Christians suffer the same afflictions, therefore they
ought to loue another. Natura asfert, saith the Orator, Pro Muraena, vt cis faueamus &c. Very nature doth teach vs to fauor those, which suffer the same dangers, out of the which we are deliuered. Seeing then Christians suffer the same afflictions in name, in goods, in body, and euery way, let them loue one another, otherwise they sin against the very light of nature: Secondly, Christians are renued to the image of God, and so haue the same similitude and likenesse. Now all men know, that loue ariseth of likenesse and similitude. Similitudo morum parit amicitiam: the likenes of manners begetteth friendship. What a strange thing is it then, that men will not loue those that are Christians, which are renued into the same image with themselues: doth it not plainly argue
that they haue not the image of God renued in truth, but onely in appearance? Wee know, saith Saint Iohn 1. Epistle 3. chapt. 14. ver. that we are translated from death vnto life, because we loue the brethren. Hence it appeareth, that many are still in death because they hate Christians, as it appeareth in all places: Thirdly, nature it selfe teacheth loue. Siccata tellus imbre rigari, &c. The earth being drie, desireth to be watered: when the heauens are full of water, they desire to power it into the bosome of the earth; such natural sympathy is there betwixt these creatures. Doe not they then teach vs loue? Aske, saith Iob, chap. 12. ver. 7. the beastes, and they shall teach thee, and the fowles of the heauen, and they shall tell thee, or speake to the earth, and it shall shew thee,
or the fishes of the Sea, and they shall declare vnto thee. So say I, the very insensible creatures teach vs loue: Fourthly, men are made of the same matter; yea, they breath the same aire, and yet no loue haue they one to another. It is a true saying that, Fratrum irae inter se inimicissimae the anger of brethren is the greatest anger that can be, so the hatred of Christian brethren is the greatest hatred that can be. A brother offended, saieth Salomon, Prouerbes 18. chap. ver. 19. is harder to winne then a strong Citie, and their contentions are like the barre of a Palace. Vt aqua calefactacum ad frigiditatem, &c. As water that hath beene hotte, being cold againe, is colder then it was by nature: so loue being turned into hatred, there ariseth the greatest hatred. Vt adamas sifrangi contingat,
&c. As the Adamant, if it be once broken, is shiuered into so smal pieces that they can hardly be seene; so the nearest friendshippe, if it be dissolued, is turned into the greatest hatred. This doctrine of loue, as it hath beene alwaies necessary, so especially in these times: for as our Sauior Christ saith, Mat. chap. 24. ver. 12. Because iniquity shal encrease, the loue of many shall bee cold. Excellently writeth Bernard 33. Sermon vpon the Canticles. Omnes amici et omnes inimici, &c. All friends and all enemies, all familiars and all aduersaries, all of a house and yet none at peace, all neighbours and yet all seeking their owne things. That our loue bee right Christian loue, let vs consider the kindes of loue: First, there is a naturall loue, as of parents towards their children, but
Christians must not stay there. Secondly there is a ciuil loue, as one heathen man loueth another for ciuility, neither must a Christian rest in this loue: Thirdly, there is a loue for commodity, which is the common loue of the world, and indeede this is nothing but selfe-loue. For si ob tuam causam cuiquam, &c. If thou doest profite any for thy owne sake, it is no benefite but vsury: Fourthly, there is a loue for pleasure, which loue likewise is very common in the world: this is the loue of pot-companions, of dicers and carders, which is soone dissolued. Quemadmodum ignis qui, &c. As the fire that is kindled in light matter, is soone exringuished, so loue which ariseth of pleasure, is soone put out: Fiftly, there is a christian loue, which is, when we loue men in the
Lord, and for the Lord. Saint Paul Ephes. chap. 6. ver. 1. commandeth children to obey their parents in the Lorde: that is, so farre as they commaund that, which the Lord commandeth them; so wee must loue men in the Lord: If by reason of loue, they will vs to doe vnlawfull things, we must rmember that it is better to obey God then men. Now we loue men for the Lord: first because he hath commanded vs so to doe: secondly, because of the graces of God which we see in them; and this is right christian loue, and they who cannot loue men, because they see the graces of God in them, plainely shew, that they haue not christian loue. What shall wee thinke then of those, who hate Christian men because they are Christians? As St. Iohn saith, surely they are not
passed from death to life, and therefore are in a fearefull estate. And thus much touching the friendly compellation. Now I come to the remoouing of the wrong conceit of the fierie trial, which is the second part of this portion of Scripture. The remouing of this conceit is very necessary, for the godly haue beene much troubled with the prosperity of the wicked, and with their owne miseries and calamities. O Lord, saith Ieremy chap. 12. ver. 1. if I dispute with thee thou art righteous, yet let me talke with thee of thy iudgements: wherefore doth the way of the wicked prosper, why are they in wealth that rebelliously transgresse? Dauid in the 73. Psalme also saith, As for me, my feete were almost gone, my sleps had well nere slipt, for I fretted at the foolish, when I sawe
the prosperity of the wicked. The Heathen man Diogenes in Tully, in his 3. Booke De natura Deorum, vttered this speech: Improborum prosperitates secundaeque res, &c. The prosperity of the wicked reproueth all the power of God. Tully also himselfe in his Oration, Pro Flac. sayth of Hierusalem quam chara dijs immortalibus. &c. It is manifest how it was beloued of God, in that it was ouercome: thus the Heathen man iudged of Gods fauour, by afflictions and crosses. Yet further to shew the necessity of the remoueall of this conceit: if men should iudge by naturall reason, might they not thinke it strange, that a father should suffer his children to be murthered before his eyes, when hee is able to rescue them, and deliuer them? The
godly are Gods children; and is it not strange, that he should suffer them to be burned before his eyes, when he is able to deliuer them? Strange it is to naturall reason, but strange it must not bee to those, which haue sauing knowledge: the reasons shall be set downe in handling of the Apostles reason. Before I come to the handling of the same, Christian reader, meditate of as strange things in Diuinity, as the afflictions of Gods children: First, God hath concluded all men vnder sin. Rom. 11. Nostra est saith Bernard Ser. 1. De dominica prima post octa. Epi. Adami cu'pa, &c. Adams fault is ours, for wee haue sinned, although in another, and the fault shall be imputed vnto vs, by Gods righteous, although secret iudgement: Secondly, God reiected
Saul and chose Dauid: yea, hee chose some to saluation, and reiected others. Excellently writeth Augustine, Serm. 20. De verbis Apostoli tu homo, expecta, &c. Thou, O man, lookest for an answere of me, and I my selfe am also a man; therefore both thou, and I, let vs hearken to him that saith: O man, who art thou that disputest with God? Better farre is faithfull ignorance then rash knowledge: seeke for merite, thou shalt find but punishment. O depth! Peter denieth, the thiefe beleeueth. O depth! Thou seekest a reason of this, I will tremble at the deepenesse; thou reasonest, I will wonder: thou disputest, I will beleeue: A depth I see, to the bottome, I cannot come. Paul calleth them vnsearchable waies of God, and thou wilt search them. Whosoeuer
liketh not this answere, let him seeke for better learned; but let him take heede hee find not presumers. Thirdly, God hardneth whom he will: Fourthly, he punisheth those that go about a righteous worke, Iudges 20. Fiftly, he punisheth not all that commit the same sinne, Exo. 32. Fatum aspici non inspici vult, &c. Gods secrets must bee looked vpon, but they must not be looked into: beleeued they must be without curious knowledge. It is sufficient to know that they are, Vt papisiones & minuta quaedam, &c. As Butterflies and small creatures flie about the light of a Candle, vntil they be burnt; so mans minde itcheth to know secrets: it will needs touch heauenly fire vntill it vanish away, and climbe vp into the tower of prouidence, vntill it fall downe.

Thus I haue shewed thee as strange things in Diuinity, as the afflictions of Gods owne deare seruants. Now I come to the reason of the fiery tryall: The reason why God doeth suffer his seruants to passe thorow the fire, is to try them: as gold is tryed in the fire, so Gods true seruants are tryed from counterfeit seruants, by the fiery tryall of afflictions; and no doubt if GOD should send the fiery tryall, many vnsound professors would manifest themselues. Constantius meaning and intending to proue some Christians that were in his Palace, whether they were good and sound men or no, called them all forth, and said: if they would worshippe his Gods, they should remaine still with him; but if they would not, they must depart, with thankesgiuing,
for that they were not punished; but indeed he expelled those that left the true God, and fell to a false worshippe; affirming, that they would neuer be good subiects that were traytors to God. Thus we see how trials discerne betwixt good and euill; betwixt Dauid and Demas; betwixt Cephas and Caiphas; betwixt Simon Peter and Simon Magus. Let not vs then thinke the fiery tryall a strange thing, seeing by it true Christians are discerned from false Christians; as drosse is tryed from the golde by the fire. Now as the Lord hath this end in sending the fierie triall; so likewise hath he many others, as the encrease of his Church: for Martyrdome doth encrease the same Sanguis martyrum est semen ecclesiae. The blood of Martyrs is the seed of the Church. Quoties metuntur
Christiani toties multiplicantur. As often as Christians are cutte downe, so often are they multiplied. The children of Israel, Exod. 1.12. the more they were vexed, the more they encreased. By Martyrdome was Iustine Martyr conuerted. Euseb. in his 4. booke and 8. chapter citeth Iustine his words, touching himselfe, in this forme: Nam ipse ego cum Platonis dogmatibus, &c. I my selfe being a Platonist, hearing that Christians were traduced, and yet neuer daunted with death, or any fearefull punishment; thought it could not be, that this kind of men should be subiect to malice, or to the desire of vaine pleasure. Augustine in his 22. booke De ciuitate Dei and 8. chapter writeth thus of Christians; Ligabantur, vrebantur, includebantur, caedebantur, multiplicabantur.
They were bound, they were burnt, they were imprisoned, they were beaten, yet were they multiplyed. The murtherers of Martyrs, are like to those that cutte downe trees, many moe branches spring out of the rootes, then there were boughes before: so out of the ashes of Martyres arise moe Christians then were before. Thus we see a second reason and cause, why God doeth suffer his Church to passe thorow the fiery tryall: namely, the multiplication of the same. Iulius Palmer, as Master Foxe reporteth, was conuerted by the suffering of Martyrs, in the bloody persecution that was in this land. And thus much touching the second cause of the fiery tryall. The third cause of Gods fiery tryall, is to giue his seruants so suffering, a greater weight of
glory: for the momentany lightnes, saith Saint Paul, 2. Cor. chap. 4. of our tribulation, worketh an exceeding weight of glory in vs; for although good workes, as wee shall heare, deserue not, yet doeth God of his mercy plentifully reward them. Mat. 5. Happy are they which suffer persecution, for theirs is the kingdome of heauen: happy are you when men speake euill of you, and persecute you: and againe, reioyce and be glad, for that your reward is great in heauen. Nemo, saieth Chrysostome, homilia 2. in Epist. ad Colos. talem vitae, &c. No man sheweth such conuersation of life, that he can be worthy of Gods kingdome, but is wholly the gift of God: wherefore hee saith, when ye haue done all things, say ye, we are vnprofitable seruants, for we haue done but the things wee ought.
Excellently writeth Ambrose, in Exhor. ad Virg. Vnde mihi tantum meriti, &c. Whence haue I such merite, seeing mercy is my crown? What shal we say then of Papists, who make the suffering of Martyrs so meritorious, that they make vp the treasure of the Church? Against this vile and detestable doctrine, let vs remember, that Dauid prayeth thus in the 143. Psalme: Enter not into iudgement with thy seruant, O Lord, for no flesh is righteous in thy sight; and againe in the 130. hee saith, If thou, O Lorde, dost mark what is done amisse, who is able to stand? Daniel also in his 9. chap. and 18. verse, prayeth thus: We doe not present our supplications before thee for our owne righteousnes, but for thy great tender mercies. Quamuis, sayth Pope Leo 83. Epist. multorum sanctorum in conspectu, &c.
Although the death of many Saints bee pretious in the sight of the Lord, yet was not the death of any Saint a propitiation for the sinnes of the world. The iust haue receiued their crownes, and not giuen a crowne; and the faithful by their fortitude are become examples of patience, not gifts of righteousnes. Yet further to giue reasons against this vngodly doctrine: The satisfaction of Christ is of infinite value, therefore there neede no adioining of the satisfactions of Saints: to this argument Bellarmine answereth; it is meete that the passion of Saints bee not in vaine: as though the passions of saints were in vaine, except they were adioyned to the passions of Christ, to make vp the treasure of the Church. Hath not their owne Pope set downe the vse of them in
the wordes which I recited? Yea, are there not many other vses besides the making vp of the treasure of the Church: Secondly, the Saints haue receiued a full reward; there wanteth therefore nothing of their labours, which may be bestowed vpon other men, to satisfie for their sinnes: to this argument, the same answere is shaped in effect, wherefore I passe it ouer: Thirdly, if Saints could satisfie for our sinnes, then were they our redeemers and sauiours; but onely Christ is our Redeemer. To this Argument hee answereth, that they are our redeemers, which is blasphemy; for they are redeemed with the pretious blood of Christ, and neuer are they called redeemers in the whole Scripture. The blood of Iesus Christ, saith Saint Iohn 1. chap. purgeth vs
from all sinne, and in the 7. of the Reu. 17. ver. They which are come out of the great tribulation, are said to haue washed their robes in the blood of the Lamb, which Lamb is Christ Iesus. Now here a question by the way may be demanded: Did all the Saints goe to heauen immediately, as wel as Martyrs? I answere, Augustine in his 20. booke, De ciuitate Dei and 9. chapt. writeth thus: for although they are not yet with their bodies, yet their soules doe euen now reigne with him, but of a part, we vnderstand the whole, euen the rest, which pertaine to the Church; which is the kingdome of God: Ergo, the rest of the soules are not tormented in purgatory, while the Martyrs raigne in heauen with Christ. Omnis anima Deo chara, saith Nazianzen in his Oration concerning Caesarius, Postquam
corporis vinculis, &c. Euery soule beloued of God, being loosed out of the body, flyeth ioyfully vnto the Lord, and enioyeth the happinesse that is layd vp for the same. Hence two maine points of Popery are throwen down: First, Purgatory: Secondly, praier for the dead; Iniuriam facit Martyri, saith Augustine, qui orat pro Martyre. Hee doeth iniury to a Martyre, that prayeth for a Martyre; so he doth iniury to a Saint, that prayeth for a Saint, supposing him to be in misery. And as touching purgatory; Iustine in his 60. question writeth thus: Est de Diuite & Lazaro narratio euidens, &c. The history of the rich man and Lazarus is an euident narration, and a manifest representation, hauing this doctrine: that after the seperation of the soule from the body,
men neither by prouidence, neither by labour can get or obtaine any helpe. Fourthly, the Lord doth send the fiery tryall vnto his seruants, that they may be made like vnto Christ; which is, a singular vse of the fiery triall: if wee will raigne with Christ, we must also suffer with Christ: Christ was put to death, and that we may be conformable to Christ our head, wee that are his members must looke for the same death. Neque, saith Cyprian, nobis est ignominia pati &c. Neither is it a shame for vs to suffer of our brethren, that which Christ hath suffered: neither a glory for them to doe that which Iudas did. Againe, saith the same worthy Martyre: Filius Dei passus est, &c. The sonne of God suffered to make vs the sonnes of God, and shall not men suffer that
they may continue the sonnes of God? Wherefore remember this fourth end, why God doeth lay vpon his seruants the fiery tryall; which indeede should moue all Christians to endure the same, if there were nothing els in the fiery tryall. Fiftly, the Lord doth send the fiery tryall to exercise the graces that he hath bestowed vppon vs: for in the fiery tryall is exercised our faith, whereby wee beleeue the promise of God; therefore faith is defined in the 11. of the Heb. to be a ground of things that are hoped for, and an argument of things that are not seene. Secondly, hope is exercised, which waiteth for the reward that is beleeued; and these are two graces of God, that stay euery Christian man in temptation: faith apprehending the promise, and hope
looking for the reward promised. If humane hope, cōforteth & strengthneth men in their miseries; how much more shold a christian hope strengthen Christians? Spes facit vt videat cū terras vndi{que} nullas, naufragus in medijs brachia iactet aquis, hope maketh him that hath suffered shipwracke, when hee can see no land, to cast and spread his armes in the middest of the waters. Againe, spes etiam valida solatur compede venctum, crura sonant ferro sed canit inter opus. Hope comforteth the prisoner, his legges make a noise with chaines, yet is he merrie at his worke: Other ends of the fiery triall, might I haue recited but I desire breuitie, I come to the vses of this doctrine: First if men must not thinke the fierie triall a strange thing, what shall we thinke of those that will bee Christians,
and yet cannot abide small trialls; as the losse of name, of goods, and health for Christ his sake: Let vs remember that which Cyprian writeth: Nec Christiani vltra durare, aut esse possumus si ad hoc ventum est, vt proditorum minas & insidias pertimescamus: Neither can wee continue or be Christians any longer, if it be come to this, that we feare the threatning and deceiptes of wicked men. The second vse of the doctrine, is to shew that all things worke together to the good of Gods children: Rom. 8.28. ver. For doth not the Fierie triall helpe them sooner to Heauen; which is the place that they long for: yea heere wee may see, how he ordereth the sins of tyrants to his owne glorie: They that doe afflict and vexe Gods Church, do sinne most grieuously; yet this affliction God
willeth, as Peter saith: 1. Epist. 4. cap. 19. ver. they which be afflicted by the will of God, let them commit their soules to him in well dooing as vnto a faithfull Creator. Excellently wtiteth Fulgentius libr. 1. ad Moni: Deus itaque licet author &c. That is, God therefore although hee bee not the author of euill thoughts, yet is hee an orderer of euill wills, and by the bad worke of euery wicked one, he ceaseth not to effect that which is good. To Fulgentius agreeth Augustine in his booke, De gen. ad literam: Vitiorum non est author deus, sed est ordinator. God is not the Author of our sinnes, yet is hee the disposer of them. The third vse of the doctrine is to shew the truth of Religion in that men will die rather then they will forsake their Religion, is it not a thing aboue Nature, that men
should rather loose their liues then forsake their beleefe in God. Memorable is the speech of Ignatius, Frumentum ego dei sum, bestiarum dentibus molor & subigor, vt panis mundus efficiar Christo: I am the Lord his corne, I care not to bee ground with the teeth of beastes, so be it I bee made fine bread for Christ: But some will say, haue not Heretiques their Martyrs; yes, but mark the difference in three things. First in the cause, Non paena sed causa facit Martyrem, not the punnishment but the cause maketh a Martyre. Secondly, marke the patience of true Martyrs. Thirdly, marke the multitude. The Diuell hath his Martyrs. As he hath his religion and his Sacraments: so hath hee also his Martyrs, for he doth amaze their sences, so that they feele not the grieuousnesse of the
punnishment which they suffer. To conclude this text of holy Scripture, if thou feelest thy frailtie and doubtest that thou canst not abide the fierie triall; Remember this saying of Cyprian Deus adiuuat dimicantes, vincentes coronat, retributione pietatis paternae remunerans in nobis quidquid ipse praestitit & honorans quod ipse perfecit. God doth helpe those that striue, hee crowneth those that ouercome, rewarding in vs whatsoeuer hee hath wrought, and honouring whatsoeuer he hath perfected: Againe remember what Ambrose writeth in his first booke of offices 38. Chap. Gratia praeparandus est animus, exercenda mens, stabilienda ad constantiam, vt nullis perturbari animus possit terroribus, nullis frangi molestiis, nullis suppliciis cedere. The mind is to be prepared with grace,
and to bee established vnto constancie, that it may not bee troubled with any terrours, nor dismayed with any sorrowes, nor yeelde with any punishment. The Lord of his infinite goodnes make vs to suffer with Christ, that we may raigne with Christ.

div.head: THE YOVNG MANS Scripture.

q.p: Reioice O yong man in thy youth and let thine hart cheere thee, and walke in the waies of thine hart and in the sight of thine eyes: but know that for all these things God will bring thee to iudgement.

div.p:
THis portion of holy writ may be called the Youngmans Scripture. The Minister hath his
scripture. 1. Tim. 3. chap. 2. ver. He must be apt to teach. St sacerdos est saith Hierom vpon the 2. of Haggey Sciat legem dei: si ignoratlegem, ipse se arguit non esse sacerdotem domini: If a man be a minister, let him know the lawe of God, if hee knoweth not the lawe, he proueth himselfe not to be the Lords Minister; Yea the learned father Augustine in his fourth booke, De doctrina Christiana 16. chap. writeth thus, Tres apostolicas Epistolas ad Titum, & ad Timotheum, ante oculos habere debet, cui est in Ecclesia doctoris persona imposita. Hee ought to haue before his eies the three Epistles of Paule to Titus and Timothy, who doth susteine the person of a teacher in the Church. The Magistrate also hath his Scripture 82. Psalme: I said yee are Gods but yee shall die like men: The rich man hath his scripture.
1. Tim. 6. chap. 17. ver. Charge them that are rich in this world, that they bee not high minded, and that they trust not in vncertaine riches, but in the liuing God: that they doe good and be rich in good workes and ready to distribute and communicate. The poore man hath his scripture, Pro 30.9. verse: Giue mee not pouertie, least I be poore and steale, and take the name of God in vaine. The olde man hath his scripture Esay 65.20. There shall bee no more there a child of yeares, nor an olde man that hath not filled his daies, for hee that shall be an hundred yeares old, shall die as a yong man, but the sinner beeing an hundred yeare old shalbe accursed. Lastly, the yong man hath his Scripture euen the text now read vnto you: In which these two things are to be considered. The first is a taunting cōcession in these words;
Reioice O yong man, &c. Or an Ironie which is, when by pronunciation, wee signifie a diuerse thing, from that which the wordes doe sound. The second thing is a bridle or restraint for the yongman in these words; but know that God will bring thee to iudgement for all these things: Touching the Irony or mocking of the yong man, it may bee questioned how it can be lawfull. I answere, when it tendeth to instruction, and not to seduce and deceiue men, then it is good and lawfull and may bee vsed. Examples whereof we haue in God himselfe in Elias, mocking the Priests of Baall, and the Apostle Paul who when hee would reproue the follie of such as did boast of such things as they had not, hee did greatly abase himselfe and aduance the Corinthians, by
such a kinde of speaking: Now to the meaning of the words touching the worde Reioice; wee must not vnderstand onely that which the Philosophers call ioy or reioycing; which is the mirth of the minde, and commeth not to the outward parts, but also outward mirth, and all kinde of vnlawfull pleasures: Yea the abuse of lawfull pleasures, and touching the worde Young man: wee must not vnderstand him onely that is of the age betwixt thirtie yeares and fortie yeares, as the Philosophers take the young man; who diuiding age into infancie, childhood and striplinges, youth and olde age make young age begin at thirtie yeeres and to reach to fortie: but we must further stretch the signification of this worde; Solomon also diuideth not onely the Young man, but also
the old man that followeth his pleasures: but he nameth the yong man, because by reason of yeeres, hee is especiallie giuen to pleasures. Furthermore Solomon nameth the hart, & saith, let thy heart cheere thee and the eies also, and walke in the waies of thine eies, because as the Rabbins say, these two members are the brokers of sinne, the hart lusteth or desireth, and the eie seeth. That which the eie seeth, the heart desireth, therefore Iob saith, I made a Couenant with mine eies, why then should I lo • ke on a maide; And thus much touching the meaning of the Irony. As concerning the meaning of the restraint of the Young man, it needeth not any explication: Now to the doctrine. Hence wee learne, that young men are wonderfully addicted to their pleasures, so are
many olde men also, but young men especiallie; therefore Solomon derideth them, because they are so addicted vnto them, Wherewithall, saith the Prophet Dauid 119. Psalme, 9. verse. Shall a young man redresse his way? because youth is giuen most to licentiousnes: he admonisheth thē to frame their liues betime to Gods worde; A young man is set as it were in a place where two waies meete, and vnto him come two tempters: the one vertue, the other vice and pleasure, as there did to Hercules: Vertue commeth with chaste eies and modest attire: Pleasure commeth with wanton lookes, with a painted countenance, and with whorish attire: Vertue saith, if thou wilt attaine to felicitie, and if thou wilt bee happie, thou must take paines; but pleasure saith, if thou
wilt follow mee, I will shew thee a pleasant life, thou shalt care for nothing, but for fine meates and drinke: but how thou maiest lie easily and play continuallie, thus the young man is tempted: Vertue propoundeth vnto him labour, if hee will be happie: Vice propoundeth vnto him pleasure, a cleane contrarie way. Now the young mans nature being prone and readie to leaue labour and to follow pleasure embraceth the same. Hence it is plaine, that pleasure fitteth the young mans nature; and indeede what doth hee thinke of; what doth hee speake; of what doth hee dreame; what doth he follow: pleasure, nothing but pleasure; hard it is for a man to resist anger, but harder it is to resist pleasure; pleasure is ingrafted and nourished vp with men. Secondly, it
is continuall, anger is but short: Thirdly, anger is bitter, pleasure is sweet: Fourthly pleasure is spred through the whole bodie: Fiftly, pleasure is fraudulent and deceitfull. Seeing then the case standeth so, that pleasure is diffused through all the parts of man, and is naturall vnto him, needes must hee follow the same, as the fish then is taken with the baite, so are young men taken with pleasure: Wherefore let mee speake to thee that art a young man, deale with pleasure, as if thou wouldest deale with a dogge, if thou desirest to be rid of him, thou driuest him away; for if thou doest feede him he will abide with thee: so if thou desirest to be rid of pleasures, chastise them that they may fly away, if thou dost foster them they will remaine still. Againe; Si vis in perpetua voluptate
manere, non voluptatibus adiiciendum sed cupiditatibus detrahendum: If thou wilt liue in perpetual pleasures, adde not to thy pleasures, but take from thy desires. Now let vs see the particular pleasures that men are giuen vnto, to omitt the pleasure of smelling; for although pleasure doth increase by smelling garments, yet I will omit to speake of this pleasure. To omit then the pleasure of smelling, and to come to the pleasure of tasting, how many men are ouercome with gluttonie and drunkennes, so that they make themselues the diuels swine; but I haue spoken and written of these sinnes, wherefore I passe them ouer. Secondly, how many men are ouercome with the pleasure of hearing tales and musicke, tending to adulterie and to whoredome; and to this head I referre
the pleasure of prophane dancing, a sinne of which I haue likewise spoken: I thinke it were better for some to follow their children to punishment, then to prophane dancing, tending to whorish vice; for if they followed them to punishment, they might be brought to repentance: but in dancing they are so commended that many of them are ledde vnto hell by it. The third pleasure is the pleasure of seeing, to which may be referred the pleasure of getting riches, yea of whoredome, for many men haue eies full of adultery, as Peter speaketh, 2. Epist 2. chap. And as whoredome may be referred to this head, so likwise may it be referred to the fourth plesure of touching: of which I wil say nothing: seeing then pleasure is such a deceiptfull harlot, that it deceaueth al the
senses, let vs beware of it: vultu, voce fallit & veste, She deceaueth by her voice, by her countenance, and by her garments: By her voice she deceaueth the eare, by her countenance the eie, by her sweete garments the sense of smelling: but some man will say, what must wee doe then, seeing pleasure is so deceiptfull, and deceaueth the senses? I answere, that wee must watch ouer our senses; My sonne saith Solomon 23. of the Pro. 25. ver. Giue mee thine heart, and let thine eies delight in my waies: And againe in the 4. of Prou. 23. Keepe thine heart with all diligence, for thereout commeth life; the senses are the windowes of the minde, they are also the doores of the same, eyther to let good or bad thinges into it; Wherefore as Iob made a Couenant with his eies, so must men
make a couenant with their senses that they beholde no euill things: Non debent sensus, ad instar petulantis ancillae foras euagari, our senses ought not to wander abroad, like vnto wanton maids; this made Zenocrates to say, nihil interest pedes an oculos in aliena ponas domo, It is no matter whether thou fastenest thine eies or thy feete in another mans house: Wherefore as the Mariners leaue not the Sea, but decline the rockes of the Sea; so we must not leaue the world, but decline the wickednes of the same; and as Vlisses stopped his owne eares and his companions with waxe, that they might not heare the inchantments of the Syrens; So must wee stop our eares, yea vaile all our senses, that wee heare not the inchantments of the world: Wherefore O young men
shut your eies, stop your eares, least you bee bewitched with the vaine pleasures of this world; can you not put a difference betwixt flatterie and true friendship: pleasure is but a flattering friend, in a worde it is a deceiptfull enemie; Qui cauet ne decipiatur, vix cauet: saepe is cautor captus est: He that taketh heed least hee be deceiued is not alwaies warie enough; for sometime hee is caught, bee hee neuer so warie. Now that men may auoide pleasures, I will set them downe these reasons, why they should doe so. First let the yong man remember that pleasure is short, but the punishment is eternall: voluptas breuis, paena aeterna. Salomon in the 7. chap. of Eccles. and 8. verse saith; that as the noise of thornes vnder a pot, so is the laughter of a foole: as the thornes crackle for a while and
profit nothing, so doth pleasure: Cogitate saith Cato, si quid per laborem recte facitis, labor cito recedit, benefactum remanet, si quid per voluptatem nequiter, haec cito perit et illud numquam abibit: Consider if you haue done any thing wel bypaines the paines is quickly gone, the good worke remaineth still; but if you haue done any thing wickedly through pleasure, the pleasure soone perisheth, but the wicked deede neuer departeth: the Iewes vse, that the new married folke, doe breake a glasse, to signifie the fragility of humane things. Secondly, the companion of pleasure is sorrow and griefe: Ita dijs placitum, voluptati vt maeror comes consequatur. So it pleased God, that sorrow should follow pleasure as a companion: Quam mira res est, saith Plato in Phaede, quam homines
appellant voluptatem, quamque miro modo se habet ad dolorem. What a strange thing is that which men call pleasure, and how wonderfully doth it respect griefe? He which layeth hold on pleasure, laieth hold also on griefe; so that they are knit together, as it were by one head: this might be specified by many examples, as of dicing, dauncing, and drunkennesse; but I forbeare them, and come to a third reason, why men should forsake their pleasures. Thirdly, there is a satietie of pleasure, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 there is a satietie of al things, and therefore of pleasure: the reason of this Aristotle giueth, Ethic. 7. the last chap. because our nature is not simple, but compounded of diuers things; wherefore, saith he, Deus vna & simplici in perpetuum voluptate perfruitur:
God doeth enioy one simple delight for euer, because his nature is most simple, and without composition. If there were any man of Philoxenus his mind, who wished that he had a Cranes necke, that he might take more pleasure in his banquets; yet would there be a satietie in his delight: is there not a satiety of any pleasure which man taketh in hand, so that hee leaueth one pleasure and taketh another in hand? and this argueth that a man is sicke in his very pleasures: Proprium aegrotantium est nunc vnum nunc aliud velle, fastidire cibos, lectum, modo huc modo illuc impatienter se conuertere. It is the propertie ofsicke men, sometime to will this, sometimes that; to loath meate, euen the bedde also, and impatiently to turne himselfe, sometimes hither, sometimes thither.
Fourthly, pleasures make the voluptuous men that are addicted vnto them, stocks and fools: Whoredome and wine taketh away the mind, saith Hosea, chap. 4. ver. 11. and needes must they so doe, for they drie the braine much, they trouble the spirits to much; they wound the phantasie: yea, they stirre vp exceeding griefes in the desire. Hence it is, that very few addicted to these pleasures, are turned vnto God: it is a principle in Philosophy that excellens sensibile corrumpit sensum, the obiect of the sense, being too vehement, corrupteth the sense; as it may be seene in those that dwell neare to the riuer Nylus, whose fall depriueth them of their hearing; so the vehemency of pleasure depriueth men of their senses.

Fiftly and lastly, there is a woe
in Scripture, denounced against those that follow their pleasures: VVoe vnto them that are mightie to drinke wine, and to them that are strong to power in strong drinke. Esay 5. ver. 22. VVoe vnto them that drink wine in bowles, and annoint themselues with the chiefe oyntments, but no man is sory for the affliction of Ioseph. Amo. 6. ver. 6. In the damnation of the rich man, this is alledged; Luke 16. ver. 25. Remember that thou in thy life time receiuedst thy pleasure, and likewise Lazarus paines: but now is he comforted, and thou art tormented: to be then in continuall pleasure, ease, wealth, peace, and prosperity in this world is perilous, and a signe of paines in the next: and here by the way men may obserue, that it is no maruell, though there bee many Papistes; for the Papists religion is a
very pleasant religion to corrupt nature; there is musicke for the eares; goodly Images for the eies; yea, delights for the other senses; yea, there is pleasure for the flesh: for what care many to commit whoredome, seeing by confessing to a Priest they may haue their sins pardoned? Yea, is not this religion very pleasant to Priestes themselues? who, as Aluarius writeth,
• aepe cum parochianis mulieribus quas ad confessionem admittunt, scelestissime fornicantur, do oftentimes commit fornication most wickedly with the women, that doe confesse their sinnes vnto them: if they say that satisfaction is enioyned them, which is very grieuous. I answere with the Prophet Michah, chap. 6. ver. 4. Will the Lord be pleased with thousands of Rammes or with tenne thousand riuers of Oyle:
Shal I giue my first borne for my transgression, euen the fruit of my body for the sinne of my soule? Noting, that there is nothing so deare, but that Hypocrites will giue, rather then leaue their sinnes: Magnum non est sua, magnum est se relinquere. It is no great thing to leaue goods; it is a great thing to leaue himselfe.

But now me thinkes I heare the young man, saying, Tush, I may follow my pleasures in my youth, and repent when I am olde. The young man is content, that God should haue the blinde, lame, and sicke sacrifice: but, saieth Malachy, chap. 1.8. Offer it vnto the Prince, will he be content with thee, or accept thy person, saieth the Lord of Hostes? But for the further abandoning of this base minde, remember these things which I shall set downe: First remember, that late repentance
may bee iustly suspected; Nam si quis quinquaginta annis tibi insestus, cum te ad regiam dignitatem &c. If a man should liue thy enemy fifty years, and seeing thee preferred to a Kingdome, should then seeke thy friendshippe, wouldest thou trust him? So is it to bee thought of those, who despising God, haue serued the diuell; and yet at the last houre will turne vnto God: it is to be thought I say, that they doe it more for feare of punishment, then for loue of the Iudge: Secondly, if thou repentest when thou art olde, it is to be feared that thy sinnes haue left thee, and that thou hast not forsaken thy sinnes: Peccata tua te dimiserunt, non tu pecca tua; thy sinnes haue giuen thee a Diuorce, thou hast not giuen thy sinnes; which is a very fearefull estate: Thirdly, remember
that it is late then to begin to liue, when wee must die: Quam serum est tunc viuere incipere, cum desinendum est? How late is it then to take in hand a new life, when we must goe out of this life? Fourthly, it is the Diuels perswasion, to giue him the present time, and God the time to come: Giue me, sayeth the Diuell, the time that now is; giue God the future time; giue me thy youth, and God thy olde age; giue me thy pleasant time, and God thy vnprofitable time: seeing this is the Diuels perswasion, that seeketh the destruction of thy soule, neuer yeeld to the same.

Fiftly, quam stultum est inde velle aetatem disponere, quo pauci perduxerunt? How foolish a thing is it then to dispose of thy age, when fewe haue liued so long: many are dead we know before gray haires.
Sixtly, Non te pudet reliquias vitae tibi reseruare, & id solum tempus bonae menti destinari, quod in nullam rem conferri possit? art thou not ashamed to reserue to thy selfe the dregges of thy life, and to appoint onely that time for repentance, which can be bestowed vpon nothing? vt ex amphora primum quod est sincerissimum fluit, grauissimum quodque & turbidum subsidet: sic in aetatequod est optimum, prius est, as out of a vessell the purest liquor runneth first out, the filthy remaineth in the bottome, so in our life that which is best, is first. Seauenthly, remember that it is a hard thing to leaue custome in sinne, custome is another nature as it were, and therefore will hardly be forsaken. Eightly, remember that repentance is the gift of God, and his giftes are not at thy commaund.
Ninthly, remember the tyrannie of death, yea the paine which thy sicknesse may bring, it may be will hardly suffer thee to thinke of repentance; how darest thou then deferre repentance. Tenthly, the sinnes of thy youth should bee most grieuous vnto thee; the Prophet Dauid in the 25. Psalme, 7. verse, prayeth thus: Remember not the sinnes of my youth nor my rebellions, but according to thy kindnes remember thou mee, for thy goodnesse sake O Lord: These reasons may suffice to make any young man to abhorre to delay repentance; but some will say, will you depriue a man of all pleasures? God forbid, but in thy pleasures remember these rules. First measure thy pleasures by the end, if they tend to nourish sinne they are naught; hence iudge of dancing of men
and women together which nourisheth whoredome; if Plato would haue euery Poet to be cast out of a commonwealth, how much more should this kinde of dancing be banished the common wealth? Secondly, hereby iudge of plaies which yeeld the very seeds of wickednesse, Histrionici gestus, saieth Lactantius Epit. diui Insti, quibus infames foeminas imitantur, libidines quas saltando exprimunt, docent. The behauiour of plaiers wherby they doe imitate infamous women, do teach lust which they do expresse by dauncing. Secondly, measure thy pleasures by time, see thou vsest them not out of time. Blessed art thou O land, when thy Princes eate in time for strength, and not for drunkennes, saith Solomon. Eccles. 10. chap. Thirdly, see that thy pleasures for the matter bee
lawfull. Aristotle, 4. Ethic. 1. numbreth the dicer among illiberall persons, and saith, hee is giuen to filthy gaine. Socrates in Zenophon in his first booke of Re. saith, that dicers are idle persons: let dicers therefore looke that the matter of their play bee lawfull. Fourthly, measure thy pleasures by thy abilitie, and see that they bring thee not vnto pouertie; this hath hunting and hauking done to many. Fiftly, see that thy pleasures bee recreations, not vocations. Saint Paul 1. Tim. 5. chap. 6. verse, saith that the widdow that liueth in pleasure, is dead while shee liueth, so say I of those that liue in pleasures, and make recreations their vocations. Seneca 55. Epistle saith of an idle person, that hee is dead, the same may bee said of him that maketh pleasure his calling.
Sixtly, see that thy pleasure make thee more fit to serue God, For voluptates illae solum verae habentur quae actionem pii perficiunt: those are onely true pleasures, which perfect the actions of godly men. Seuenthly, in thy pleasures begin with praier, that God may blesse them vnto thee 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 saith Nazianzen, it is the best order that can bee, to begin in God and to end in God. Eightly, in all thy pleasures remember the day of Iudgement, know that God will call thee to iudgement: But yet further some will say the life of a Christian is without pleasure, therefore who can endure it? O foole, deceiue not thy soule, the life of a Christian is the most pleasant life that can be, for spirituall delights are farre better then bodily delightes, the reasons
are many. First, man is more delighted in that he vnderstandeth things, then in that hee perceiueth them by sense; because it is a more excellent knowledge. Secondly, the knowledge of the vnderstanding, is more beloued then the knowledge of the senses, for there is no man that had not rather want his bodily sight, then his sight of his soule, which is his vnderstanding. Thirdly, the spirituall good which causeth ioy, is greater then any bodily good: men wil abstaine from many bodily pleasures, that they mayobtaine honour: but some will say how commeth it then to passe, that bodily pleasures are more followed after? There are diuers causes. First bodily pleasures are better knowne. Secondly, they are preseruatiues against griefes of the bodie, which
man cannot endure, vt quidam morbo aliquo & sensus stupore suavitatem cibi non sentiunt, sic libidinosi, auari facinorosi &c. As they which are sicke feele not the sweetnes of meate, so they that are giuen to lust, to couetousnes and wickednes, feele not the sweetnes of true pleasure: I haue had, saith Dauid 119. Psalme, a great delight in the way of thy testimonies, as in all manner of riches: And againe, except thy lawe had beene my delight I should haue perished in mine afflictions: and thus much touching the first part of my text. Now I come to the second: which is a bridle and restrainte to keepe the young man from his pleasures: but know saith Solomon that God wil bring thee to iudgement for all these things: In which words I will handle three thinges. First what
Iudgement is; Secondly, the diuersitie of iudgements, Thirdly, the vse of the doctrine. Touching the first to omitt the diuerse significations of the worde iudgement: Iudgement is an act of a Iudge, either absoluing or condemning any person: this to bee true, no man can denie, Christ is the iudge of the quicke and the dead, and hee will either absolue them, or condemne them: Absolue them hee will if they bee members of his mysticall bodie; condemne them he will, if they liue in their sinnes without repentance; touching the diuersities of iudgements, there are two iudgments, the one particular: the other generall: The particular iudgement euery man hath at his death: the generall iudgement, shall be at Christ his second comming.
For the proofe of this particular iudgement, it is euident that the wicked are carried to eternall punishment, 16. of Luke and the godlie to eternall rewards: but it is no way probable, that the rewards should be rendered before iudgement: therefore at the houre of death there is a particular iudgement. Chrysostome in his 37. Homilie vpon Mathew doeth make this plaine; Postquam, saith he, Diem tuum obieris, iudicium & paena consequetur: After thou art dead, iudgement and punishment will follow: In which place, hee confuteth those, that thinke that Christ will bring the dead to repentance: he vseth this argument; after death there followeth iudgement, and after iudgement punishment; therefore there is no place for repentance. By the way wee
may obserue, what is become of Popish Purgatorie, wherefore wee must hold with Augustine, lib. 2. De Origi. Animae. cap. 2. Illu • rectissime & valde saiubriter credit, iudicari animas cum de corporibus exierint, antequam veniant ad illud iudicium, quo cas oportet iam redditis corporibus iudicari. He doth very well beleeue, that the soules are iudged when they goe out of their bodies, before they come to that iudgement, in which they shall bee iudged with their bodies. But some will say, Then to what end serueth the generall iudgement? I answere, there are many causes of the same: First, that the mercy and iustice of God might be made manifest, God hath made all things to declare his glory: the wicked might accuse him of iniustice, therefore he will haue the same made manifest to the
whole world, as likewise his mercy in the saluation of his seruants.

Secondly, God will haue his son Christ Iesus, publikely to be glorified, and honoured: He was publikely dishonoured in this world, therefore his father will haue him publikely honoured at the day of iudgement.

Thirdly, the Lord will haue his seruants publikely honoured: the Saints haue been made a spectacle to men in this world, therefore he will haue them honoured before the whole world. Fourthly, whole man must bee iudged and receiue his reward, both in soule and in body; therefore there must be a generall day of iudgement. Fiftly, the workes of men are not ended at their death: the wicked men by their examples, writings, and many euill deedes, doe much hurt, euen
after their death: and the godly after their death, doe much good by writings; therfore when there shal be an end of good and euill works, which shall bee at the end of the world, then shall be a generall day of iudgement: And that there shal be a iudgement, it is plaine by many reasons: First, many wicked men escape vnpunished in this life, therefore seeing the Lord is righteous, he must needes punish them in the life to come: wherefore excellently speaketh Isocrates in his Parae. Iusti, si nulla alia re iniustis praestant, spe certe bona sunt superiores. If the iust excell the vniust in nothing, yet are they better in respect of hope: Secondly, the conscience of a man doth declare euidently, that there shall be a iudgement, for that will accuse him most fearefully, after sinne, which is a liuely representation
of a iudgement to come: therfore conscience is called, before sinne be committed, a bridle; and after sinne, a scourge or whippe. To giue one or two examples: Pausanias after he had rauished Cleonice, how fearefully was he troubled? Her shape did appeare vnto him in his sleepe, and threatned punishment, saying, paena tibi luenda est thou must be punished. Nero hauing murdred his mother, as Suetonius writeth Saepe confessus est se exagitari materna specie, oftentimes acknowledged, that hee was tormented with her shape: Thirdly, there are iudgments in this world; therefore there is a Iudge of the world: God hath fearefully punished many sinners, as swearers, adulterers, vsurers, euen in this life; which is an euident argument, that there is a iudge of the world. Excellently
writeth Augustine in his 1. booke De ciuit. Dei, chap. 3. If God should punish no sinne in this life, his prouidence would not be beleeued: if he should punish al sinne, nothing would be thought to bee reserued to the day of iudgement. Fourthly, it is an article of our beleefe, that Christ shall come to iudge the quick and the dead: Fiftly, Sibill hath prophesied of Christ his second comming to iudgment, writing thus: Tunc castus Christus ponet certamina iusta, ornabitque probos aeternaque praemia reddet. Then chast Christ shall compound all controuersies: hee shall beautifie the good, and giue them euerlasting rewards. Now I come to the vses of this doctrine, which are many: first, it should make the Ministers diligent in preaching; I charge thee before God, saieth Saint Paul, 2.
Tim. chap. 4. ver. 12. and before Iesus Christ, who shall come to iudge the quicke and the dead, that thou preach the word, &c. Secondly, it should teach Magistrates to iudge righteous iudgement, for they haue a Iudge in heauen: Thirdly, it should teach men to be fruitfull in good workes: for although workes deserue nothing, yet shall men be iudged according to works, because they doe declare a man to bee in Christ Iesus. Fourthly, it teacheth men to abstaine from all vncharitable iudgements, for God is our Iudge: Fiftly, it teacheth men, little to esteeme these vnchristian censures, that men will giue one of another: Sixtly, it teacheth all men to haue a cleare conscience; for if our conscience doe condemne vs, God is greater then our conscience: Seuenthly, it should stay
mens mindes from the greedy desires of this world: Lastly, it should teach young men to absteine from the vnlawfull pleasures of this life, Know that God will bring thee to iudgement, whosoeuer thou art that art addicted to thy pleasures. Sed quam caecus inest vitiis amor? Omne futurum, despicitur, suadentque &c. But alas, how blinde is the loue of vice? all things to come are despised; things present perswade, profite and pleasure, neglecting punishment, causeth men to transgresse, while that punishment is deferred. Thus much shall serue to haue spoken of this text: the Lord of his infinite goodnesse and mercy grant, that in al our thoghts, wordes, and deedes, wee haue the day of iudgement before our eyes.

div.head: THE DIFFICVLTIE of Saluation.
div.p:
OVr blessed Sauiour Iesus Christ immediatly before these wordes, had taught this doctrine: that rich men are hardly saued, which he made manifest by aprouerbiall speech: It is harder for a
Camell to goe thorow the eye of a needle, then for a rich man to enter into the Kingdome of heauen; vpon which doctrine and prouerbe, the Disciples inferre this question: Who then can be saued? as if they had said, then is saluation indeede a difficult matter; for rich men haue the most especiall meanes to be saued: they haue wealth, wherby they may get knowledge; but, as Solomon saith, Prouerbes 17. ver. 16. Wherefore is there a prize in the hand of a foole to get wisedome, and he hath no heart? Againe, they haue whereof to releeue the poore; so that they make them friends of the vnrighteous Mammon, Luke 16. ver. 9, Make you friends, saith our Sauiour Christ, with the riches of iniquitie, that when yee shall want, they may receiue you into euerlasting habitations: Furthermore, they haue
leisure to pray and instruct their families, but they haue no care of these dueties. For the further explaining of the words; the word Who is sometime a word of mourning, as Gal. the 5. ver. 7. Ye did run well, who letted you, that yee did not obey the truth: Non interrogantis est illud quis, sed deplorātis, saith Oecumenius, that Who is not a word of asking, but a word of bewailing. Secondly, this word Who is a word of exhortation, Hos. 14. ver. 10. Who is wise, that he may vnderstand these things? so likewise in the 107. Psalme, Who is wise, that he may obserue these things? and Ier. 9. ver. 11. Who is wise, that he may vnderstand this? Thirdly, this word Who is a word of wondering, Esay 53. ver 1. VVho hath beleeued our report! Fourthly, it is a word of questioning, and so it is in this place: VVho
then can be saued? Now concerning the word Saued: sometimes by saluation is ment temporall saluation; that is preseruation: 1. of Tim. 4.10. God is said to be the Sauiour of all men, especially of those that beleeue, that is the preseruer. Psalme 36. ver. 6. Thou Lord dost saue man and beast: that is, thou preseruest them. But in this place it noteth not preseruation, but eternall saluation, as in many other places of holy scripture; the words then doe not deny saluation to rich men, but note the difficultie of saluation. Here two errors are to be auoided, the first is we must not thinke that riches are vnlawfull for christians: the holy Scriptures do euery where forbid thefts, and commend almes; which would neuer haue bin done, if riches had bene vnlawfull for Christians: The second errour is,
wee must not thinke that almes is sufficient vnto saluation, without saith, hope, loue, repentance, and other graces of God: for, saith our Sauiour Christ, Luke 13. Except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish: and Saint Paul 1. Cor. 13. saith, If I feede the poore with al my goods, and though I giue my bodie to be burned, and haue not loue, it profiteth nothing. Saint Augustine in his 21. booke De ciuitate Dei, 22. writeth thus: qui fecerit (inquit) elemosynas, quamuis mores in melius non mutauerit, sed inter ipsas suas elemosynas, &c. There are some that hold, that hee which giueth almes, although hee mendeth not his life, but liueth wickedly; yet shall he haue iudgement with mercie: so that he shall neuer be condemned, or els he shall be deliuered out of damnation, eyther after some short or long time. This is
a damnable opinion, for the Scripture euery where requireth vnto saluation, a change of our liues; yet should it seeme, that some are possessed with it, euen in these daies, for there are fearefull cursers, vsurers, and such as liue in other sinnes; yet because they giue now and then almes to the poore, they expect and looke for saluation: these two errours being avoided, now I come to the handling of the text. The doctrine which ariseth from thence is this: namely, that it is an exceeding hard matter for a man to be saued: yea, indeede it is a wonder that any man attaineth vnto saluation: to make this point plaine, is it not a great worke to make something of nothing? If thou wilt be saued, God must work as great a worke for thee, for thou must be a new creature, 2. Cor. 5.
ver. 17. If any man be in Christ Iesus, let him be a new creature: so Gal. 6.15. saith Saint Paul, for in Christ Iesus, neither circumcision auaileth any thing, nor vncircumcision, but a new creature. Againe, Ephes. 2.10. for we are his workemanshippe, created in Christ Iesus, vnto good workes: so then is it as great a matter for any to be saued, as to be created? Yea, in some sort greater; for when God created the world, he found nothing to resist his will, but in this new creation of man, he findeth the peruerse will of man, to resist his will; which peruersenes he must take away. Secondly, men are dead in their sins by nature, Ephes. 2.7. Is it not a wonderfull worke to raise a dead man, and to giue him life? Euen so is it to raise a man out of the graue of his sinnes, and to giue him a spirituall life. Excellently therefore
doeth Aquinas hold prima secundae 113. quae. Ar. 9. that iustificatio impij est maximum opus Dei. To make an vngodly man righteous is the greatest worke of God. Iudicet qu • potest, saith Augustine, Trac. 72. in Ioh. vtrum maius sit iustos Angelos creare, quam impios iustificare, certe si aequalis est vtrumque potentiae, hoc maioris est misericordiae. Let him iudge that is able, whether it is a greater matter to create the Angels righteous, or to iustifie the vngodly man; that is, to make him righteous: verily if both be of equall power, yet is it a worke of greater mercy, to make an vnrighteous man righteous. To come to particulars, it is a harder matter for a rich man to be saued: First, in respect of pride, for he is in danger to be proude, 1. Tim. 6.17. Charge them that are rich in this world, that they be not high minded.
The Prophet Hos. chap. 13. verse 6. saith of the Israelites, that they were filled, and their heart was exalted. I know, saieth Cato in Gell. in his 7. booke and 3. chapter, that most men by prosperity do waxe proud; but this should not be, for quemadmodum arboris ramus quo est plenior, eo est grauior: euen as the bow of a tree, the fuller of fruit it is, the lower it is: so the more blessings the Lorde doe bestow vpon men, the more humble they should be. Agricolae saith Plutarch, libenter vident spicas quae vergunt ad terram, quae enim ob leuitatem sursum attolluntur, inanes sunt. Husbandmen doe willingly behold eares of corne that turne towards the earth; for they which looke vpward are emptie, and haue nothing in them: so may I say, God regardeth the humble, but the proud he scorneth. Seeing
then rich men bee in danger of pride, and they which will be saued must be humble, it must needes be, that it is a hard matter for rich men to be saued. Esto, saith Chrysostome in his Homily Profec. Euangelij. multumaedifices, habeas elemosynas, preces, ieiunia, virtutsque omnes, humilitate non praeiecta, frustra & in vanum erunt omnia, facileque ruet super arenam extructum aedificium. Be it thou buildest much, thou mayest haue almes, prayers, fastings, al vertues; yet if humilitie be not laide for a foundation, all is in vaine, and thy building will easily fall, beeing but vpon the sand. Secondly, it is hard for rich men to be saued, in respect of putting their trust in riches: Charge rich men, saieth Saint Paul in the place before cited, that they trust not in vncertaine riches. For this cause Ephes. 5. ver. 5. a couetous
man is called an Idolater, because he putteth his trust in his riches; not onely because in respect of riches, he neglecteth the seruice of God, but because he thinketh that his life doeth consist in riches; therefore I say, is he called an Idolater. Riches through the corruption of men, do marueilously steale their hearts from God, for they will no longer trust God, then they see him in their Barnes or Chests. Giue me not, saith Agur 30. of the Prouerbs, 8. verse, pouertie nor riches, feede me with foode conuenient for me, least I be full, and denie thee, and say, VVho is the Lorde? meaning, that many rich men put their trust in their riches, and so denie God. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . To make many Gods, is no better then a kind of Atheisme: seeing then the rich man doth make many Gods, he
is in danger to denie God; and seeing he is in danger of both these: to make both many Gods, and to denie God, it must needes bee a hard matter for him to be saued. Thirdly, it is a hard matter for a rich man to be saued in respect of couetousnes: the more riches doe encrease, the more they are desired. The desire of riches is like vnto a dropsie, crescit indulgens sibi dirus hydrops; the more he that hath the dropsie drinketh, the more he desireth; so the more riches that a rich man hath, the more he desireth: insomuch that physick doth encrease the disease. Thirst is quenched with drinke, hunger with meate, but the thirst and hunger of riches is neuer satisfied. Excellent therefore is the speech of the holy Prophet Dauid in the 62. Psalme, If riches encrease, set not your hearts vpon them. There
be three things that will not be satisfied, saith Agur, Pro. 30.15. yea, foure that say not, it is enough: the graue, the barren wombe, the earth that cannot be satisfied with water, and the fire that saith not, It is enough. The same may be said of couetousnes, it is neuer satisfied: qui plus cupiunt, sic diuitias habent, quomodo habere dicimur febrem: diceredebemus, febris illumtenet; sic Diuitiae illum possident, non ille Diuitias. They that desire more, possesse riches as a man is said to haue an ague; we should say the ague hath him: so riches possesse him, not he riches: wherefore Christian brother, whosoeuer thou art, learne to moderate thy appetite, concerning riches; for they that will be rich, saith the Apostle, 1. Tim. 6.9. fall into temptation and snares, and into many foolish and noysome lusts, which drowne men in perdition
and destruction. A poore man needeth many things, a couetous man all things. As men cannot vse a horse without a bridle, no more can a man vse riches without moderation of his appetite: the best riches then are want of the desire of riches. Fourthly, rich men are hardly saued in respect of pleasures, for many of them, are exceedingly addicted vnto a voluptuous life, and indeede liue in no calling; onely pleasure is their calling, as if God had euer ordained any such calling: They take the Tabret and the Harpe and reioyce in the sound of Organs. Iob 21.12. I take not away pleasures from men, but I desire to temper them with an holy and Christian vocation. If the heathen man said, that qui ad eruditionem aspirant, iis omittendae sunt omnes voluptates, relinquenda studia delectationis,
ioci conuiuium, sermo etiam pene omium familiarium deserendus. They which aspire to learning, must abandon pleasures, relinquish delights, and forsake mirth, banqueting; yea, the talke almost of familiar friends: how much more may I say, that they which will atteine to the Kingdome of heauen, must abandon their delights and pleasures. Let no man thinke that God hath placed them in this world, to be the seruants of pleasures, but that they should follow after vertue: many men desire to be accounted valiant; here is valor and strength to be shewed: namely, in vanquishing their pleasure: Haniball when he was nine yeares olde, sware that he would be an enemy to the very name of a Roman: we in baptisme vowed to relinquish pleasures, yet doe not men
forsake the same: If Euripides, as Plutarch reporteth, findeth fault with those that vsed musicke at their banquets, because it is to bee vsed for comfort and solace, and not to weaken mens minds with pleasure: how much more may they iustly be found fault withall, that vse nothing els but pleasures and pastimes? Hence is it that they are so nice, that they can beare no afflictions. Excellent is the counsell of Isocrates:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Exercisethy selfe in voluntarie labours, that thou maiest beare necessary afflictions: but enough of this point. Fiftly, rich men are hardly saued in respect of cruelty: for many of them are cruell oppressors. To this head I referre Inclosers, who turne men into sheepe; so that they dispeople
townes, and disteeple Churches. I cannot more fitly resemble these men, then to Aesops Lyon, who said, one part is mine, because I am most worthy, another is mine because I am strongest, the third is also mine, because I laboured most, and if you will not also graunt mee the fourth part, and indeed all, fare-well friendshippe: so saith the Incloser, one part is mine, I am most worthy, for I am a Gentleman; an other part is mine, I am strongest, for I am wealthiest, the third part is mine, for I paid for all, and touching the fourth part, except thou wilt also graunt me that, fare-well friendshippe. If the eloquent Prophet Esay in his 5. chap. and 8. verse, denounced a woe vnto th • se that ioyne house to house, and lay fielde to fielde, till there bee no place, that they may be placed themselues in the middest
of the earth. Why should not a woe be denounced against those that ioyne fielde to fielde, so that there bee no Commons for the poore, nor corne and graine for them: haue not those Inclosers forgotten the law of nature, which is, to doe as men would be done vnto? Would they be thus dealt withall themselues? I pray God that these Inclosers inclose not the Diuell in their Pastures, and their soules in hell. Againe, to the head of crueltie I referre vsurie: the vsurer may be fitly resembled to lightning, which melteth the monie in the purse, and neuer hurteth the purse. Loculis integris, (saith Seneca) pecunia, quae in his fuerat, conflata reperitur: quia ignis tenu • ssimuper occulta foramina transit. The Lord in the 23. of Deut. ve. 19. saith plainely, Thou shalt not giue to vsury
to thy brother, as vsury of money, vsury of meate, vsury of any thing, that i • put to vsury. Hence I thus conclude; to no brother must we lend vpon vsury, but all Christians are brethren: Ergo, to no Christian must we lend vpon vsury. If it be obiected, that the Iewes were permitted to lend to strangers; I answere with Ambrose, Cui iure inferuntur ar ma, huic legitime indicuntur vsurae: they that might lawfully be killed, might lawfully be oppressed with vsury; and in very deed the practise of the Iewes doth manifest this permission in some sort, for one Iew will not lend to another vpon vsury; if he doth, he is condemned by the law of God; and shall one Christian then lend to another vpon vsury? My purpose is not to handle this same at large, therefore I leaue the vsurer
condemned by Gods law, by mans law, by the law of nature, and by his owne conscience, and say with Plautus, Quid est danista? genus hominum improbissimum est. What is an vsurer? It is a most wicked kind of men, for indeed he is worse then a Iew; for one Iew will not take vsury of another, but the vsurer wil take vsury of his Christian brother: hee is worse then death, for death killeth but the bodie, but the vsurer killeth both bodie and soule. Lastly, to this head of cruelty, I referre oppressing Land-lordes, who, as Galba made his Citizens most drie sponges, so these men make their tennants: their rents are now set vpon the tenter-hookes, and they grind the faces of the poore, not considering that they are the Lords tennants: and lastly, not thinking vpon the saying of Iulius Caesar,
misera comes senectutis, est pristinae crudelitatis memoria. The remembrance of olde crueltie, is a miserable companion of olde age. Alexander being asked where hee had his tresures, answered at his friends: so cannot those raking Land-lords say, for few friends haue they: this is a crying sinne, and day and night it maketh such a noyse in the eares of the Lord, that he will not heare the prayers of those oppressing Land-lords. The Land-lord now a dayes letteth his grounds best, that destroyeth his tennants: if any man marueile at these thinges, let him remember, that old age inclineth to couetousnes. Hoc vitium affert senectus hominibus, attentiores sunt omnes ad rem, quam sat est: This is the fault of olde age, it is too much giuen to the worlde; no maruell then, though men bee
exceedingly addicted to this sinne. Sixtly, rich men are hardly saued, in this respect, that they are impatient of reproofe, which is a meanes to saue mens soules. The rich man thinketh that he must not be reproued, for hee is a certaine God vpon the earth: Diues quasi Deus. If a Minister now a daies crie vae vobis, Woe vnto you rich men: it will be hard, if they bring him not coram nobis, before the Magistrate. Minucius, as Liuie reporteth, sayde eum esse primum virum, qui recte consulit; eum secundum, qui bene monenti obtemperat: qui nec bene monet nec paret, extremi ingenij esse, that hee was the best man, that could giue good counsaile; he was the second that did obey, but he that did neyther giue good counsell nor obey, was of a nature to bee deplored. What nature then haue these rich
men, that will neither giue good counsell nor take good counsell? Take none they will not, for they cannot abide to bee reproued: reprouing is rayling in their corrupt iudgement. But let them knowe, that Isocrates the Heathen man could put a difference betwixt these two. Nam accusare putandi sunt (saith he) qui laedendi causa conuicia dicunt; admonere, qui propter audientium vtilitatem, idem faciunt. They are said to accuse that tell men of their faults to hurt them, but they doe admonish that tel men of their faults, for their good: seeing then that rich men are tolde of their faults for their good, and not for their hurt, let them put a difference betwixt railing and reproofe.

But howsoeuer these men are impatient of reproofe, let the Minister
do his duety; let him not be Lapis laeuigatorius, a sleeke-stone to soothe and smoothe men in their sinnes. Woe vnto them that call euill good, and good euill: sinne is sinne in whomsoeuer it is found, whether he be rich or poore, God respecteth no mans person: let the rich man then as he deserueth, haue his reproofe. Seuenthly and lastly, a rich man is hardly saued, for he is in danger to breake all the commaundements of God, or the most of them: he is in danger of Idolatrie, as I shewed before: yea, is he not in danger of swearing? And doe not rich men now a daies cracke oathes, as the bird Sitta cracketh nuts? Doeth not the rich man most wofully prophane the Sabboth, in vsing faires and worldly busines vpon the same? Furthermore, he is disobedient to his parents,
for he careth not for the Ministers of Gods word, who should be his fathers: yea, hee careth not to murther by not feeding the poore: and what careth hee to commit whoredome, because by his wealth he can countenance his sinne? Stealings, false witnesse, and coueting are his daily sinnes. Seeing then that these things are thus; how hard is it for a rich man to be saued? But some man will say, is it not also hard for a poore man to be saued? Yes very hard: for when our Sauiour Christ saith, It is hard for a rich man to be saued, hee doeth not denie, but that it is also hard for a poore man to be saued. The affirming of the one, doeth not make a deniall of the other; and indeede it is also exceeding hard for a poore man to bee saued: First, a poore man is in danger of impatiencie
in respect of his pouertie. How doe the poore fret and murmure against God, because they are in want? Secondly, it is a hard matter also for a poore man to be saued in respect of enuie, for the poore men enuie the estate of rich men, and pine away with sorrow, that any are in better estate then themselues: this is a very fearefull sinne, for they should reioice at the good one of another, as members of the same Mysticall bodie. The poore and the rich meete together (saith Solomon, Pro. 22.2.) the Lord is the maker of them all. Againe, inuidia ipsa maximam partem veneni sui bibit. Enuy drinketh the greatest part of his owne poyson. The Serpents keepe poyson without their owne hurt, and powre it out to the hurt of others; but the enuious man keepeth his enuie, which is
poyson, to his own hurt, and powreth it out to the hurt of others, and to the ruine of his owne soule. Thirdly, it is hard for a poore man to be saued, in respect of lying, for because hee is poore, hee thinketh that he may lye to releeue himselfe. Fourthly, it is hard for a poore man to be saued, in respect of stealing; for to helpe himselfe, he careth not to commit this sinne. Giue me not pouerty (saith Agur, Prou. 30.8.) least I be poore and steale, and take the name of God in vaine. Now let not any man take me thus, as if rich men would not murmure, as if they were not enuious, or would not steale; or as if poore men might not be proude, couetous, or cruell: but as it is said in the 25. of Ecclesiasticus, ver. 2. Three sorts of men my soule hateth, and I vtterly abhorre the life of them: a poore man
that is proud: a rich man that is a lyar, and an old adulterer that doteth: So then it is monstrous for rich men to lye, as it is for poore men to be proude.

Furthermore I might shew that it is a hard matter for them both to be saued: I meane both poore and rich, in respect of buying and selling; for as a naile in the wall, sticketh fast betweene the ioynts of stones, so doth sinne sticke betweene buying and selling, Eccles. 27.2. But I come to the vses of the doctrine: The first vse of the doctrine is this: namely, that men ascribe their saluation to God alone, not partly to him and partly to themselues, seeing saluation is as great a worke as creation. Excellently writeth Bernard in his booke of free-will, Id totum gratia Dei est, quod creamur sanamur, & saluamur. It is the meere grace of
God that wee are created, that we are made whole, and that wee are saued. Againe, saith Augustine in his sentences, Ad caelestis Hierusalem consortium non ascendit, nisi qui toto corde profitetur, non proprij esse operis, sed diuini muneris, quod ascendit. He ascendeth not to heauen, who doth not acknowledge with his whole heart, that it is not by his owne worke, but by Gods gift, that he ascendeth thither. Furthermore, saith the same Augustine, lib. 2. De peccatorum meritis & remissione cap. 18. laborant homines inuenire, in nostra voluntate quid boni sit nostrum, quod nobis non sit ex Deo; & quomodo inueniri possit ignoro. Men doe labor to find in our wil, what good is ours, which is not of God; but how it should bee found I know not. Lastly, in his 106. Epistle he writeth sweetly; gratia Deisic operatur,
vt nec voluntas accipientium praetermittatur vel adiungatur, sed subsequatur; quandoquidem tantum beneficium non solum non libentibus sed etiam reluctantibus datur. Gods grace doth so worke, that neither the will of him that receiueth it, is past ouer or ioyned with the same grace, but followeth it, seeing so great a benefite is not only giuen to those that are not willing, but euen to those that resist the same. The second vse of the doctrine is this; seeing it is so hard a matter to be saued, let men take paines in this busines of saluation: hard matters must be laboured: wonderfull it is to see what paines men take in the things of this life, but most pitifull, to behold what little paines they take in the busines of saluation, as if it were a matter of no labour. Thirdly, seeing it is so hard
a matter, both for rich and poore to be saued; let them eschue the sinnes that hinder their saluation: let the rich man eschue pride, pleasure, couetousnes and voluptu ousnes: let the poore man eschue impatience, enuie, lying and stealing. Lastly, seeing it is so hard a matter to attaine vnto saluation, what thankefulnesse ought they to render to GOD, who hath wrought this great worke of saluation in them: laudabo deum ob beneficium creationis: sed magnificabo & extollam eum ob beneficium redemptionis. I will praise God for the benefite of creation; but I wil magnifie and extoll him for the benefite of redemption. It cost him the blood of his owne Sonne to saue men, so did it not in the worke of mans creation. The Lorde of his infinite and great mercy worke
this great worke of saluation both in rich and poore, both in high and low: if this be not wrought in them, it had bin good for them they had neuer beene borne.
